22.advice: Pickup, instrument or connecting cable may be defective; substitute with one known to be good if possible (especially the cable).

23.advice: See that tubes are firmly seated in their sockets. Also any internal wiring using plugins; must be secure.

24.advice: Check tubes: if possible substitute tubes known to be good, one at a time, starting with the output tubes. Common output tube types are: 6V6, 6L6, 5881, EL-37, EL-34, EL-84, KT-66, ^BG6, 6BQ5, 7591, 7027A.

25.advice: Replace rectifier tube. This is probably a 5U4, 5Y3, 6X4, 6X5, 6AX5, 5V4, 6CA4, 5AR4.

26.advice: Follow the same procedure with the rest of the tubes: the pahse inverter and voltage amplifier tubes; Common tube types: 6SL7, 6SN7, 12AY7, 12AU7, 12AT7, 6CG7, 6EU7, 7025.

27.advice: Disconnect the speaker. Use test speaker or test amplifier to determine which is distorting.

28.advice: Check Preamp Tubes. Most common Preamp Tube types are: 6SL7, 6SN7, 12AX7, 12AY7, 12AU7, 12AT7, 6C5, 6J5, 6SC7, 6CG7, 6EU7, 6AN8. If amplifier has more than one of these, try interchanging, using Preamp Tube from the channel that sounds OK in channel that distorts.

10.advice: Spekaer, leads and output transformer secondary OK.Take amplifier to a competent repair service.

11.advice: Unplug cable from instrument and touch the tip of the plug.

12.advice: Check cable between instrument and amplifier.Repair or substitute with a good cable.

13.advice: Check and repair pickup on instrument.

14.advice: Check wall outlet. Plug in something you know that works.

15.advice: Replace fuse on amplifier (fuse could be defective and stillappear to be OK.

16.advice: Check line cord, plug or on-off switch.

17.advice: Check for short in amplifier.Sobstitute tubes if possible and by prcess of elimination locate shorted one. Especially tubes such as 5Y3, 5U4, 5AR4, 6V6, 6L6, 7591, 7027A, EL-37, 5881.

18.advice: Take amplifier to a competent repair service.

19.advice: Check for blown house fuse and replace it.

2.q: Are tubes and pilot lamps lighted?

3.advice: Check controls on amplifier for normal setting.Instrument controls should be all the way on.Also check standby switch, if any.

4.advice: Turn volume all the way on and listen to hum.

5.advice: Substitute tubes with known good ones.

6.advice: Unsolder one of the wires from speaker.Touch one end of a flashlight battery to the unsoldered speaker wire,the other to the empty speaker terminal. Listen for a click from speaker.

7.q: Can you hear the clicking sound?
7.advice: Defective speaker, leads or uoutput transformer.Apply flashlight battery voltage directly to speaker termianls.

8.advice: Speaker is OK, the trouble is in the speaker leads or output transformer.Repair leads by yourself or take amplifier to a competentrepair service.

9.advice: Voice coil on speaker open; replace speaker.

20.q: Is sound distorted on all channels?

21.advice: Control settings may be too high, especially volume.
